title-group.article-title: Mild and Selective Trifluoromethylation of Peptides at Tryptophane Residues by a Water‐Soluble Copper Complex with Redox‐Active Ligands

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). Chemistry – A European Journal published by Wiley‐VCH GmbH

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Selective chemical modifications of biomolecules are in high demand for the development and implementation of chemical biology strategies. Methods involving radicals have emerged as powerful options yet potentially generate side reactivities when involving harsh reaction conditions. We report the development of a mild catalytic method for the selective functionalization of tryptophane residues in peptides with a trifluoromethyl group using a water‐soluble copper complex with redox‐active ligands. This method displays both inter‐ and intramolecular selectivity for tryptophane residues and its synthetic relevance is demonstrated by the selective conversion of a 13‐residue peptidic sequence and an endomorphine analogue in good yields.

Selective functionalization of aminoacids is a key endeavor in chemical biology. Radical manifolds offer interesting possibilities but can suffer from limited control over radical processes, resulting in a lack of selectivity in product distribution. A water‐soluble copper complex with redox‐active ligands has been developed and performs trifluoromethylation of tryptophane residues with high selectivity. This method displays both inter‐ and intramolecular selectivity and its synthetic relevance is demonstrated by the selective conversion of a 13‐residue peptidic sequence and an endomorphine analogue in good yields.

sec.title: Introduction

caption.p: Synthetic methods for the introduction of CF3 groups in peptides.
a) Synthesis of proligand 1 and water‐soluble copper complex 2; b) X‐ray crystallographic structure of 1, and c) structure of Cu(SQ)2.

sec.title: Synthesis and Characterization of a Water‐Soluble Copper Complex

caption.p: a) UV‐vis spectrum of complex 2 in MeOH; b) X‐band EPR spectrum in frozen solution (100 K) of 2 in methanol. Experimental conditions: microwave frequency 9.31 028 GHz; power 0.12 mW, modulation 2 G. The red line is the simulation assuming an effective spin S = 1/2 : g values (gx= gy=2.045gz= 2.208), 63,65Cu hyperfine parameters (Ax= Ay= 55 MHz and Az= 565 MHz) and a superhyperfine interaction with two equivalent nitrogen nuclei (Ax=Ay= 50 MHz and Az= = 65 MHz).

Cyclic voltammograms of complex 2 recorded in DMSO + 0.1 M of (n‐Bu)4 N, PF6 a), and in H2O + 0.1 M of KNO3 b), with a glassy carbon disk electrode. Conditions: concentration of 2:1 mM; scan rate : 0.1 V×s−1; T = 25 °C. The black traces show the cyclic voltammograms recorded on the full potential range, whereas the red traces show the voltammograms restricted to the cathodic region and the blue trace the voltammogram restricted to the anodic region.

sec.title: Reactivity of Complex 2

caption.p: Trifluoromethylation of Boc‐tryptamine 3 catalyzed by complex 2.
Reaction optimization for trifluoromethylation of model dipeptide 6 catalyzed by complex 2.

sec.p: The applicability of the method was investigated on two N‐acetylated tryptophan‐containing peptides of variable lengths (WG and GGWG) under the optimized conditions. Excellent yields for the CF3 incorporation were obtained in both cases (Scheme 3a). We next assessed the compatibility of complex 2 with peptide amine (H‐GGWG‐NH2) 9a containing an unprotected N‐terminus (see Supporting Information Section 7.2.1.) and unfortunately, a fast disappearance of the starting peptide was observed by HPLC but did not lead to the expected product 9b (Scheme 3b), possibly resulting from competitive chelation of the copper center by the peptide free amine terminus. The effect of a lateral chain bearing a primary amine on the reactivity was explored by synthesizing peptide Ac‐GGWGK‐NH2 10a (Supporting Information Section 7.2.2.) containing a lysine residue and led to a similar observation (Scheme 3b), thus confirming that 2 is not compatible with primary amines, either as N‐terminus NH2 or in lateral chains. The kinetics of the conversion of Ac‐GGWG‐NH2 into Ac‐GGW(CF3)G‐NH2 8b under optimized conditions was followed by HPLC, and peak areas were used to estimate conversion (Figure 4). The trifluoromethylation reaction exhibits first‐order kinetics (t1/2 = ln(2)/k) with a half‐life of 81 minutes.

caption.p: Scope for trifluoromethylation of peptides with N‐acetylated or free amine N‐terminus. *Yields were determined by analytical HPLC.
Consumption of starting peptide Ac‐GGWG‐NH2 (black curve) and formation of product 8b (red curve) monitored by HPLC.
Selectivity experiments on aromatic aminoacid residues Trp, His, Tyr, and Phe.*Yields were determined by analytical HPLC.

sec.p: To gain insights into the mechanism, a UV‐vis spectroscopic study was performed (Figure S48). The intervalence band observed for complex 2 disappears upon addition of oxidative reagent 4, thus suggesting an electron transfer between the two partners. The reaction mixture shows a similar profile, and the titration of complex 2 with increasing amounts of reagent 4 shows gradual disappearance of the bands that becomes complete upon addition of one equivalent. Addition of TEMPO to the reaction mixture shuts the reaction down, thus suggesting a radical mechanism. From these combined mechanistic observations, it can be assumed that complex 2, designed as a water‐soluble version of Cu(SQ)2, performs the reaction through a similar mechanism involving a radical manifold initiated by ligand‐based SET (single electron transfer) to generate a CF3 radical followed by addition of this radical on the substrate (Scheme 5). The resulting trifluoromethylated radical then undergoes oxidation to the cation while the catalyst is regenerated by a second SET to the singly oxidized copper intermediate. This mode of action explains the observed differences between methods A and B. The first one relies on the catalytic and controlled generation of radicals, while the second one involves a classical initiation/propagation radical chain mechanism under strongly oxidative conditions, thus leading to harsher conditions and the rise of polytrifluoromethylation. Furthermore, the selectivity of method A is also reinforced by the fact that the trifluoromethylated aminoacid becomes less nucleophilic and less reactive under these conditions.

caption.p: Plausible mechanism for the trifluoromethylation reaction.

sec.p: Finally, we studied intramolecular selectivity by synthesizing a peptide containing both Tyr and Trp residues within the same sequence (Scheme 6). This peptide exhibits very low solubility in water or buffer medium, and the amount of DMSO was increased (6:4 DMSO/H2O). After 5 hours, a product with a molar mass corresponding to the incorporation of one CF3 group was detected by LC‐MS analysis and could be isolated in 21% yield after preparative HPLC purification. LC‐MS/MS analysis indicated ionic fragments consistent with a trifluoromethylation of the Trp fragment, and no fragment corresponding to CF3 incorporation on Tyr was detected (Figures S55‐S58). Attempts to convert this peptide with method B were unsuccessful due to its low solubility. However, similar experiments conducted on smaller and soluble acetylated endomorphine (containing Trp, Tyr, Phe, and His) led to selective trifluoromethylation at the tryptophane residue in 23% yield with method A (and none at Tyr, Phe, and His), and no reaction with method B. These experiments confirm the excellent chemoselectivity (Trp over Tyr, Phe, and His) of the copper‐catalyzed method, which could be attributed to the easier rearomatization of the radical after addition in the case of tryptophane than in the case of tyrosine.

caption.p: Intramolecular selectivity experiment between Trp and Tyr residues within a) a 13‐residues single peptide, b) peptide analogue of medicinal interest. *isolated yield, and c) observed fragments in tandem MS/MS.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We have developed a highly chemo‐ and regioselective catalytic method for the mild and biocompatible trifluoromethylation of peptides. Although so far limited to peptides with N‐acetylated terminus, this study shows enhanced selectivity toward tryptophane residues compared to reported methods and opens the door to the development of bioinspired catalysts for biomolecule modifications.

sec.title: Experimental Section
sec.p: Experimental details, characterization data of compounds, crystallographic data, and spectroscopic data are provided. CCDC 2 451 598 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_‐request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1 223 336 033.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available in the supplementary material of this article.
